title: Around college football | Houston thrives under former Ohio State coach | Buckeye Xtra Sports
text:
The college football world couldn’t help but take notice last season when then-Ohio State offensive coordinator Tom Herman was able to turn third-string Buckeyes quarterback Cardale Jones into a championship-winning one.
Now the first-year coach of No. 21 Houston, Herman is again giving people reason to pay attention.
>> Get the most out of your Ohio State experience, follow @BuckeyeXtra on Twitter 
The Cougars (6-0, 3-0 American Athletic Conference) enter their road game today at Central Florida (0-7, 0-3) a victory shy of just their fourth 7-0 start in school history. Herman said his task now is ensuring that his team understands it’s only that — a start.
“We are built that way. The culture around here has been ingrained,” Herman said. “We have a bunch of older, senior leaders that understand they only give you your senior year once. They want to make sure they are not remembered as the team that won their first six games, and then X, Y, Z happened, and went to the so-and-so bowl.”
 
FRIDAY’S GAME No. 18 Memphis 66, Tulsa 42: Paxton Lynch completed 32 of 44 passes for 447 yards and four touchdowns to help Memphis (7-0, 3-0 American Athletic Conference) defeat host Tulsa (3-4, 0-3) for its 14th consecutive victory.
Dane Evans passed for 421 yards and four touchdowns for Tulsa.
Wisconsin, Illiniois feature tough defenses It’s been a while since Wisconsin and Illinois met when the game meant this much to both teams.
The Badgers (5-2, 2-1 Big Ten) need a win in today’s game to stay within sight of Big Ten West-leading Iowa. And Illinois (4-2, 1-1), less than two months after seeing its coach fired, isn’t out of the race, either.
In a season of defense in the Big Ten, the Badgers and Illini have two of the conference’s better units.
Wisconsin is ranked seventh nationally in total defense, giving up 272.3 yards per game. The Badgers are even better in scoring defense, giving up a slim 10.9 points per game. Only Alabama (35 points) and Nebraska (21) have managed more than 10 points on them.
“The edge guys and their linebackers are so active,” interim Illinois coach Bill Cubit said. “They’ll find out what your protection is and they’ll find a way to get their best player on your worst player.”
The Illini spent the previous two seasons giving up big yards and a lot of points. But this season, they are ranked a solid 30th in the country in total defense at 332.5 yards per game. Illinois is giving up 19.7 points per game to rank 28th.
Illinois has beaten Wisconsin just once in the past 10 meetings.
Cincinnati, Marshall agree to games Marshall and Cincinnati have agreed to renew their rivalry.
The schools 150 miles apart will meet twice beginning in 2017, when the Bearcats will play host. The Thundering Herd will play host in 2019.
The teams last met in 2008, when the Bearcats won 33-10 in Huntington, W.Va. Cincinnati leads the series 8-3-1.
Georgia running back Chubb has knee surgery Georgia running back Nick Chubb is expected to make a full recovery after surgery on his left knee on Friday.
Chubb, one of the nation’s top players, suffered torn ligaments against Tennessee two weeks ago.
